fields.name: Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya
fields.address: 159-161, Mahatma Gandhi Road, Fort, Kala Ghoda, Fort, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400032
fields.description: Grand museum with Indo-Saracenic architecture featuring history exhibits, cultural art & education.

fields.name: Dr. Bhau Daji Lad
fields.address: 91 A, Rani Baug, Veer Mata Jijbai Bhonsle Udyan, Dr Ambedkar Road, Byculla East, Byculla, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400027
fields.description: Mumbai's first museum showcasing the city's cultural heritage with artistic & decorative artifacts.

fields.question: The bronze statue found in 1926 in the MohenjoDaro area of the Indus valley civilization is called
fields.options: ["Great Indian girl", "Lady of Indus", "Dancing Girl", "The Harappan Girl"]
fields.hint: The statuette is 10.5 centimetres (4.1 in) tall, and depicts a young woman or girl with stylized proportions standing in a confident, naturalistic pose
fields.trivia: Although it is in a standing position, it was named "Dancing Girl" with an assumption of her profession. This is one of two bronze art works found at Mohenjo-daro that show more flexible features when compared to other more formal poses

fields.question: The following is a famous painting by Robert Alexander Hillingford
fields.options: ["The man with a book", "A soldier's sermon", "The demurral of a leader", "A warrior's paradox"]
fields.hint: Its an oil Painting belonging to the 19th Century British provenance
fields.trivia: Contains a man with a book

fields.question: The painting depecting the episode the Draupadi vastrapaharan from Mahabharata is called
fields.options: ["Triumph of Devotion", "A queen's agony", "The lord's miracle", "A prayer answered"]
fields.hint: Its a wash on paper belonging to the bombay school paintings collection
fields.trivia: PENDING

fields.question: Judge no one happy until his life is over
fields.hint: the Painting of Sword hanging over a man
fields.trivia: Damocles is a flatterer courtier of Dionysus the Elder of the 4th century B.C. tyrant king of Syracuse. Dionysus asks Damocles whether he would he like to try out Dionysus' life. Damocles readily agrees. Damocles enjoys everything immensely until he notices a sharp sword hovering over his head that is hanging from the ceiling by a strand of horsehair. This, the tyrant explains to Damocles, is what life as ruler is really like.

fields.question: The man who stole the peaches of immortality
fields.hint: In this unique and finely carved statue, the man has paused to put on his shoe which he had lost in his haste. To free his hands, he is holding the peach branch between his teeth.
fields.trivia: Dongfang Shuo stole the peaches of immortality from the Queen Mother of the West. These peaches that ripened once every 3,000 years were reserved for immortals. Legend has it that Dongfang Shuo stole the peaches on three occasions and became immortal. He is considered a god of longevity by the Chinese.

fields.question: The following hindu deity is an aspect of the divine trinity
fields.hint: This idol excavated from kashmir, resides in the Industrial Arts Gallery
fields.trivia: Dattatreya, a Hindu deity, is an aspect of the Trimurti, the Divine Trinity of Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva. This Dattatreya idol illustrates the naturalistic form which developed in response to European influence on Indian art.

fields.question: The prince who was deplicted in the diaroma "Emperor Jehangir on a lion hunt" belonged to ____
fields.hint: The dioroma also contains his son Prince Khurram
fields.trivia: This theatrical diorama depicts the Mughal Emperor Jehangir engaged in the royal sport of 'shikar' or a hunt. The chief characters in the diorama are Emperor Jehangir, his son Prince Khurram or Shah Jahan and Prince Karan Singh of Mewar who was a guest at the Mughal court.

fields.question: The "People of India" is a series pf photographic illustrations depicting the daily workings of Indian weavers, artists and craftsmen. It was commissioned by ____
fields.options: ["Prince Wales", "F.M COleman", "Lord and Lady Canning", "John Forbes Watson and John William Kaye"]
fields.hint: This is a series of photographic illustrations commissioned as a souvenir of their stay in India.
fields.trivia: Images and photographs from the colonial period frequently depicted the Indian artisan at work in an effort to document the various crafts and occupations observed in India. This photographic plate shows a scarf maker seated cross-legged on the ground with his embroidery frame placed in front of him

fields.question: Sir Charles D'Oyly is one of his series, highlights the life of company servants in India from an english perspective. The series is titled ____
fields.options: ["The Indian Company", "The European in India", "The English Diaries", "Life in the east"]
fields.hint: D’Oyly served in India between 1798 – 1838 as an East India Company servant and was posted in Calcutta, Dacca and Patna
fields.trivia: His mildly satirical but they provide the readers a view into the life of a Company officer in the Romantic, pre-imperial India.

fields.question: The following term coined by art historians to denote a group of paintings that evolved due to an interaction between traditional Indian and European paintings of 18th and 19th centuries C.E.
fields.hint: Such paintings were more of a documentary nature, made by Indian artists for European customers
fields.trivia: This style of paintings was very popular among Europeans.

fields.question: Which of the following embroideries is the word "Garo" associated with?
fields.hint: Garo has become an identity for Parsi women. It is worn on special occasions as well as at marriages
fields.trivia:
Appreciative of Chinese embroidery, Parsi traders bought embroidered silks for their families and placed orders for embroidered sari borders, saris, blouses and pantaloons. The embroidery was worked on a variety of Chinese silks.
Over time, the word garo (from the Gujarati word for a sari) was associated with the Chinese embroidered sari.

fields.question: The goddess Gajalakshmi is seated on ____
fields.hint: Its called Lalitasana
fields.trivia: Goddess Gajalakshmi seated on a lotus pedestal in lalitasana. She holds a lotus flower in her hand while the right hand rests in varadamudra. The prabha consists of two female attendants seated on a lotus stalk on either side each holding a kalasa

fields.question: Ailurus fulgens is popularly known as?
fields.hint: Its is a mammal native to the eastern Himalayas and southwestern China
fields.trivia: The red panda (Ailurus fulgens), also called the lesser panda, the red bear-cat, and the red cat-bear

fields.question: Vaishravana is popularly known as?
fields.hint: The Lord of the Yakshas
fields.trivia: The epithet “Lord-Leader of the Yaksha…” mentioned in the inscription at the back denotes Vaishravana (another name of Kubera, the Lord of the Yakshas), corroborated also by iconographic details.

fields.question: Which region does the Baluchari Sari belong to?
fields.hint: Its a traditional silk or brocade sari
fields.trivia: Baluchar sari is the traditional silk or brocade sari from Bengal which gets its name from the small village of Baluchar near Murshidabad where it originated. The twisted silk warp has heavy silk as weft often in contrast colours.

fields.question: What is the above type of painting known as?
fields.hint: It belongs to a former princely state in Himachal Pradesh
fields.trivia: Kangra painting refers to the art of Kangra, Himachal Pradesh, a former princely state, which was an important centre of the Pahari school of painting. Pahari paintings, as the name suggests, were paintings executed in the hilly regions of India, in the sub-Himalayan state of Himachal Pradesh and were patronized by the Rajput rulers between the 17th and 19th centuries.

fields.question: Who does the following bust represent?
fields.options: ["David Sassoon", "Thomas Woolner", "John Henry Grose", "G. W. Forrest"]
fields.hint: He funded the construction of a Mechanics' Institute, a library, and a convalescent home in Pune and the docks in Colaba.
fields.trivia: This white marble bust of David Sassoon, created in 1865 by Thomas Woolner, likely commemorated Sassoon’s generous donation towards the construction of the Museum building, much like the six pointed star which covers the Museum’s decorative ceiling.

fields.question: The god represented in the above figure is
fields.hint: Its based on the description in the ancient Puranas
fields.trivia: The worship of Surya or the Sun dates back to early Vedic Age, with hymns dedicated to Surya in the Rig Veda. It was believed that the Sun was carried across the sky on his chariot everyday, pulled by a seven-headed horse.

fields.question: Heptanesia is a 3 Dimensional map showing?
fields.hint: Its greek for seven Islands
fields.trivia:
The 3 dimensional map of the original seven islands of Mumbai is titled Heptanesia, Greek for seven islands, which is the earliest documented name for the city recorded in the writings of Ptolemy. 
The Kamalnayan Bajaj Mumbai Gallery showcases Mumbai’s origins as a group of islands separated by swamps, marshland and mangroves, covered with coconut groves, and its development into a vibrant and elegant 19th century city.

fields.question: What is this model of a dredger known as?
fields.hint: It was presented by Bombay Port Trust Authorities in 1914.
fields.trivia:
This model of a dredger named ‘Kuphus’ was presented to the Museum by the Bombay Port Trust Authorities in 1914. 
Dredgers were large mechanisms used to gather sediments from sea bed which was later used for miscellaneous activities. 
In Mumbai (Bombay), dredgers were mainly employed for reclamation works and thus extensive stretches of land were made available for transportation, housing and businesses.

fields.question: The community of fishermen shown in the figure are known as?
fields.hint: The caste of Original fishermen
fields.trivia: The Main occupation of Koli is Fishing. Primarily they are fisherman and boatman. They are adept in various methods of river fishing and are regularly employed as a worker on a ferry. Their connection with water has led to them becoming the water-carrier for Hindus.
